Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Bridging Quantum-Mechanics with Mechanics: Towards Predictive Computations of Materials Behavior

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to develop a seamless multi-scale computational technique to study crystalline solids with defects by resolving all the relevant length-scales -- from quantum-mechanical interactions at the sub-Angstrom length-scale to the elastic fields on the continuum scale. This will be achieved by (i) developing a real-space finite-element formulation of Kohn-Sham Density Functional Theory (KSDFT) which will scale linearly with the number of electrons; and (ii) developing the quasi-continuum reduction of KSDFT using a hierarchy of adaptive finite-element triangulations which will resolve the quantum-mechanical interactions where necessary (like the core of a defect), while seamlessly coarse-graining away to capture the long-ranged elastic fields. The developed multi-scale scheme will be used to investigate the origins of plasticity in surface dominated structures like nano-pillars.

The proposed research will enable quantum-mechanics informed calculations on continuum scales by seamlessly bridging the quantum-mechanical length-scale with the continuum. Importantly, this multi-scale scheme links the material description at any length-scale to their fundamental origin -- the electronic structure. Thus, the developed method is expected to be transferable and predictive. This effort will enable an accurate quantum-mechanical description of defects in materials, and in effect will promote predictive simulations of deformation and failure mechanisms in solids. The educational efforts include developing a core-curriculum for the field of nanoscience, and developing educational modules involving simulations of materials behavior to demonstrate the importance of computations in science and technology to high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Defects play an important role in influencing many aspects of mechanical properties of crystalline materials including plasticity, creep and fracture. The nucleation and kinetics of defects are governed by their energetics, which in turn is governed by the quantum-mechanical interactions at the core of the defect as well as long-ranged elastic fields. Importantly, these vastly different length-scales are inherently coupled, which makes the study of the energetics of defects challenging as this requires large-scale electronic structure calculations.

Intellectual Merit: The research component of this project has developed computational techniques that have enabled large-scale electronic structure calculations using Kohn-Sham density functional theory on systems of the order of 10,000 atoms. This has been achieved by combining computational technique, numerical analysis and high performance computing. In particular, we developed: (i) real-space formulation of Kohn-Sham density functional theory; (ii) an adaptive higher-order finite element discretization that is amenable to considering general geometries and boundary conditions that are important in the study of defects; (iii) developing efficient computational algorithms for the solution of Kohn-Sham equations; (iv) developing a scalable parallel implementation of the computational framework and algorithms. We are using the developed capability of large-scale electronic structure calculations to study the energetics of dislocations in Aluminum.

Broader Impact: The broader impacts of this work include: (i) developing an open source code for real-space electronic structure calculations using finite element basis which includes developments pursued in this work; (ii) participated in the development of a special topics course in Quantum Mechanics and Solids State Physics in collaboration with other faculty; (iii) this project provided multi-disciplinary training for graduate students in mechanics, condensed matter theory, numerical methods and scientific computing; (iv) one undergraduate student has participated extensively in the research activities of the project; (v) one high school student spent time during summer understanding the various aspects of the research being conducted and developed an appreciation of the underlying physics, mathematics and computing involved in the research activities.
